subject: Add ubuntu bionic based ovs image
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8863, 'name': 'Andrii Ostapenko', 'email': 'anost1986@gmail.com', 'username': 'aostapenko'}, {'_account_id': 12281, 'name': 'Itxaka', 'email': 'igarcia@suse.com', 'username': 'itxaka'}, {'_account_id': 16353, 'name': 'Georg Kunz', 'email': 'georg.kunz@ericsson.com', 'username': 'georg-kunz'}, {'_account_id': 16881, 'name': 'Munish', 'email': 'mm6021@att.com', 'username': 'munish.mehan@att.com'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 17966, 'name': 'Steven Wilkerson', 'email': 'srwilkers@outlook.com', 'username': 'srwilker'}, {'_account_id': 20466, 'name': 'Tin Lam', 'email': 'tin@lam.wtf', 'username': 'tinlam'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22477, 'name': 'Matt McEuen', 'email': 'matt.mceuen@att.com', 'username': 'mattmceuen'}, {'_account_id': 23928, 'name': 'Pete Birley', 'email': 'petebirley@gmail.com', 'username': 'portdirect'}, {'_account_id': 27589, 'name': 'Deepak Tiwari', 'email': 'deepak.tiwari@aricent.com', 'username': 'deepak.tiwari'}, {'_account_id': 29668, 'name': 'cheng li', 'email': 'cheng1.li@intel.com', 'username': 'chengli3'}, {'_account_id': 30220, 'name': 'Rihab Banday', 'email': 'rihab.banday@ericsson.com', 'username': 'rihabbanday'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-14 06:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30220, 'date': '2019-06-14 10:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16353, 'date': '2019-06-14 13:55:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16353, 'date': '2019-06-14 14:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-16 08:51:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-16 08:52:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-16 09:04:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I have tested the image built from this docker file, together with the ovs patch[1] and the neutron patch[2]. With pre-allocated 2M size hugepages, I deployed openstack-helm(with dpdk enabled) without error. After that, I was able to create one instance(of course with flavor hw:mem_page_size='large'). I also was able to access Internet from the VM.

So removing 'WIP' flag

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/626894/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643284/"}, {'account_id': 16353, 'date': '2019-06-17 09:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I was also able to successfully test this image in my AIAB multi-node environment [1] - however, not using the OVS_VSWITCHD flag yet, but the update-alterntatives method.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/634207/'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-17 10:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I would suggest not using update-alternatives, as this command updates some files under /etc/alternatives. In openstack-helm, the file system is mounted in readonly mode. It means that update-alternatives fails in openstack-helm.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-06-18 08:53:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16353, 'date': '2019-06-18 09:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-18 12:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-06-18 12:43:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8863, 'date': '2019-06-18 16:03:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Previous implementation allows to build image with custom ovs/dpdk version. E.g. default OVS_VERSION was 2.10.1, however bionic latest available version is 2.9.2. As I'm aware there's use cases for that."}, {'account_id': 16353, 'date': '2019-06-18 19:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Previous implementation allows to build image with custom ovs/dpdk
 > version. E.g. default OVS_VERSION was 2.10.1, however bionic latest
 > available version is 2.9.2. As I'm aware there's use cases for
 > that.

 > Previous implementation allows to build image with custom ovs/dpdk
 > version. E.g. default OVS_VERSION was 2.10.1, however bionic latest
 > available version is 2.9.2. As I'm aware there's use cases for
 > that.

Building OVS from source comes with maintanence overhead and performance disadvantages. As we discovered previously, the version of OVS in this image needs to match somewhat the version of OVS in the Neutron and Nova images. Moreover, when building from source, you need to fix the machine architecture (e.g., to SandyBridge) to allow this community-maintained image to run on older hardware as it exists in the OpenStack infra. So, if you are after performance, you'd anyway have to use a custom-built image tuned to the machine architecture of your target machine."}, {'account_id': 8863, 'date': '2019-06-18 21:25:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

commit_message:
Add ubuntu bionic based ovs image

As we are moving to bionic version, this patch is to add ubuntu bionic
based ovs image to support ovs-dpdk. Also this patch removes the
debian_dpdk image, as it doesn't work correctly on some CPUs.

Change-Id: I3f720dfa0736cabbaa59406871b039d8762ce4de

commit_message:
hacking: Resolve W605 (invalid escape sequence)

This one's actually important since it will be an error in future
versions of Python.

Change-Id: Ib9f735216773224f91ac7f49fbe2eee119670872
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

The file is subsequently encoded as base64, which requires a
bytes-like object, not a str

Change-Id: I3d53fe98caaf1728f1d0c67de2c4a5e53deafa0e
Closes-Bug: #1834215
'}]
commit_message:
Rabbit SSL CA should be opened for reading bytes

The file is subsequently encoded as base64, which requires a
bytes-like object, not a str

Change-Id: I3d53fe98caaf1728f1d0c67de2c4a5e53deafa0e
Closes-Bug: #1834215

commit_message:
Fix iCalendar format violations

After observing errors from importing our iCal into Outlook, I found
there were a few issues with our generated output according to [0].

This adds an overall VERSION to the iCal and sets per event timestamps
and UIDs.

This also updates YAML loading to use safe_load to get rid of a
deprecation warning noticed while testing.

[0] https://icalendar.org/validator.html?url=https://releases.openstack.org/schedule.ics

Change-Id: I3803a432da2538af4de163b77c192130366ddadf
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix deployment of ceph-nfs container failing due to wrong USER

The startup script requires to be run as root, not ceph.
All other ceph images follow this rule.

Also removed redundant blank line.

Change-Id: I1d69ec0ca97dbbacccfe737fca03c9739244b900
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update hacking version to 1.1.x

This commit updates hacking version in test-requirements
and fixes some related pep8 issues

Also ignores false positive bandit test
B105: hardcoded_password_string,
B106: hardcoded_password_funcarg
based on variable or argument names.
For more info refer [1][2]

[1] https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b105_hardcoded_password_string.html
[2] https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b106_hardcoded_password_funcarg.html

Story: 2004930

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-13 20:34:20.000000000', 'message': "Make sure we install cinder requirements during the correct tox phase

When runnign tests under tox the virtualenv is created in a number of
phases (in brush strokes)
0. virtualenv -p $python .tox/$dir
1. pip install $deps
2. pip install .

Step 2 is run without any deps as they're all supposed to be installed
in phase 2

We have constraints in 'deps' we need to install all of cinders
requirements during phase 2.  If we don't then we get unconstrained
versions being installed during phase 2.

This shows up in a py27 run[1] as the absence of taskflow, and then in
[2] with new dependancies being installed

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/34/647934/3/check/openstack-tox-py27/93180f1/tox/py27-1.log
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/34/647934/3/check/openstack-tox-py27/93180f1/tox/py27-2.log

Change-Id: I5b1c285680f7c3256a707ea5973573f1176d4a26
(cherry picked from commit f12fda8ffbb42e71108701b38c09618997b836c3)
(cherry picked from commit aecb6100e296aed7235635a5b18a0835fd2aca34)
(cherry picked from commit 81bf9537018486b9c4ef7985daaec901fbdc2a1b)
"}]
commit_message:
Make sure we install cinder requirements during the correct tox phase

When runnign tests under tox the virtualenv is created in a number of
phases (in brush strokes)
0. virtualenv -p $python .tox/$dir
1. pip install $deps
2. pip install .

Step 2 is run without any deps as they're all supposed to be installed
in phase 2

We have constraints in 'deps' we need to install all of cinders
requirements during phase 2.  If we don't then we get unconstrained
versions being installed during phase 2.

This shows up in a py27 run[1] as the absence of taskflow, and then in
[2] with new dependancies being installed

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/34/647934/3/check/openstack-tox-py27/93180f1/tox/py27-1.log

[{'created': '2019-06-18 08:48:15.000000000', 'message': "Workaround pyroute2 platform-dependent imports

Pyroute2 recently changed the way they import their base namespace
ojects. Now they are somewhat platform dependent, so on OSX unit tests
will fail for lack of linux-specific libs. Using `create=true` allows
the mocks to be created even if the library doesn't think they exist.
https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/commit/b69999ec82667828816fa2a7b19d0a4f2fe06a83

Change-Id: I8f9c25e979a7e86ff0b8e19267e4525817802ba2
"}]
commit_message:
Workaround pyroute2 platform-dependent imports

Pyroute2 recently changed the way they import their base namespace
ojects. Now they are somewhat platform dependent, so on OSX unit tests
will fail for lack of linux-specific libs. Using `create=true` allows
the mocks to be created even if the library doesn't think they exist.
https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/commit/b69999ec82667828816fa2a7b19d0a4f2fe06a83

Change-Id: I8f9c25e979a7e86ff0b8e19267e4525817802ba2

[{'created': '2019-06-26 12:52:39.000000000', 'message': "Add OsProfiler config options to generated reference

OsProfiler is optional, but if it's installed we'll load up the configuration
options from the library, but they weren't in the generated config sample so
people would have to find the osprofiler docs, or worse the code, to figure
out how to configure it.

This simply adds the OsProfiler config options to the config sample, which
will also show up in the config reference docs.

Story: 2005842
Task: 34191

commit_message:
Add OsProfiler config options to generated reference

OsProfiler is optional, but if it's installed we'll load up the configuration
options from the library, but they weren't in the generated config sample so
people would have to find the osprofiler docs, or worse the code, to figure
out how to configure it.

This simply adds the OsProfiler config options to the config sample, which
will also show up in the config reference docs.

Change-Id: I4cd2c27b11c67ac67ace22bc43e09add8ac05bf0
Story: 2005842
Task: 34191

commit_message:
Revert "Add JSON driver for access rules config"

This reverts commit f028ca4edd592c45c100e7cf42cb95fe954604aa.

In the Train PTG[1] we agreed to defer this feature until we had some
kind of traceability or discoverability for APIs and that this wasn't
feasible or useful until then.

This change was merged to master but never released, so I submit that
it is safe to revert.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/keystone-train-ptg-application-credentials

Change-Id: I8fc5fcb2b35431882f0d64866765d6b0cd31356f

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-13 14:07:26.000000000', 'message': "Refresh instance network info on deletion

When deleting an instance, if the network info is empty, we should
refresh the info because we can't be sure the copy of the cache we
have when we fetched the instance to delete is up-to-date, i.e. if
we're racing to delete the server while it's building and the
network info cache was updated in the database after we started the
delete operation and got the instance from the DB, then we could
fail to unplug VIFs.

Closes-Bug: #1830081

Change-Id: I99601773406c61f93002e2f7cbb248cf73cef0ab
Signed-off-by: Arnaud Morin <arnaud.morin@corp.ovh.com>
(cherry picked from commit d4ed0d8b7adc350e8962df033c2da892c95561fe)
"}]
commit_message:
Refresh instance network info on deletion

When deleting an instance, if the network info is empty, we should
refresh the info because we can't be sure the copy of the cache we
have when we fetched the instance to delete is up-to-date, i.e. if
we're racing to delete the server while it's building and the
network info cache was updated in the database after we started the
delete operation and got the instance from the DB, then we could
fail to unplug VIFs.

Closes-Bug: #1830081

Change-Id: I99601773406c61f93002e2f7cbb248cf73cef0ab
Signed-off-by: Arnaud Morin <arnaud.morin@corp.ovh.com>
(cherry picked from commit d4ed0d8b7adc350e8962df033c2da892c95561fe)

messages: [{'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-06-26 23:16:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-06-27 06:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 23:00:29.000000000', 'message': "Nagios: Update Nagios host definition plugin

This updates the plugin responsible for defining Nagios's hosts
and hostgroups to use the Kubernetes python client instead of
querying Prometheus for this information. This results in a more
predictable and reliable list of hosts for Nagios to use, as
querying Prometheus for scalar metrics in a point-in-time could
result in a host not being added correctly in scenarios where
a host is down when Nagios is attempting to query Prometheus to
generate the list of hosts

Change-Id: I962696eac7c9cc94650666a1d3a60c610d1ae867
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Nagios: Update Nagios host definition plugin

This updates the plugin responsible for defining Nagios's hosts
and hostgroups to use the Kubernetes python client instead of
querying Prometheus for this information. This results in a more
predictable and reliable list of hosts for Nagios to use, as
querying Prometheus for scalar metrics in a point-in-time could
result in a host not being added correctly in scenarios where
a host is down when Nagios is attempting to query Prometheus to
generate the list of hosts

Change-Id: I962696eac7c9cc94650666a1d3a60c610d1ae867
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-06-26 14:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-06-26 19:22:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-26 22:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28008, 'date': '2019-06-27 01:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-06-27 06:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 911b6c4b190fc6ad8dbd938b3558fd8410e05c5a'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 14:26:14.000000000', 'message': 'Reduce the RAM allocation for the octavia amphora flavor in AIO/CI

In restrcited environments such as AIO and CI, tempest tests
can fail because the host RAM may be exhaused by trying to launch
the amphora and back end servers needed for the test.

This patch halves the memory allocation to the amphora to allow
the tests to pass. The setting is not suitable for production use
and a comment is added as a reminder in the override.

Change-Id: I19ef3733c250617a266fce98d11ab29fb548ab16
'}, {'created': '2019-06-26 19:22:34.000000000', 'message': 'Reduce the RAM allocation for the octavia amphora flavor in AIO/CI

In restrcited environments such as AIO and CI, tempest tests
can fail because the host RAM may be exhaused by trying to launch
the amphora and back end servers needed for the test.

Change-Id: I19ef3733c250617a266fce98d11ab29fb548ab16
'}]
commit_message:
Reduce the RAM allocation for the octavia amphora flavor in AIO/CI

In restrcited environments such as AIO and CI, tempest tests
can fail because the host RAM may be exhaused by trying to launch
the amphora and back end servers needed for the test.

Change-Id: I19ef3733c250617a266fce98d11ab29fb548ab16

[{'created': '2019-06-17 14:32:18.000000000', 'message': 'Miscellaneous doc/comment/log cleanups

This commit is a grab-bag of tweaks and cleanups noticed while working
in the neighborhood on something unrelated.

- Add a descriptive comment to the ResourceProviderNotFound exception.
  This is a marker exception used for inter-method communication.
- Add and enhance debug logs in the in_tree$S filter code path.
- Correct a SQL comment in get_providers_with_resource (missed when the
  code was tweaked).
- Removes a TODO about an optimization that became obsolete when
  RequestGroupSearchContext was integrated into
  get_provider_ids_matching.
- Corrects the get_sharing_providers docstring s/list/set/ to reflect
  reality.

commit_message:
Miscellaneous doc/comment/log cleanups

This commit is a grab-bag of tweaks and cleanups noticed while working
in the neighborhood on something unrelated.

- Add a descriptive comment to the ResourceProviderNotFound exception.
  This is a marker exception used for inter-method communication.
- Add and enhance debug logs in the in_tree$S filter code path.
- Correct a SQL comment in get_providers_with_resource (missed when the
  code was tweaked).
- Removes a TODO about an optimization that became obsolete when
  RequestGroupSearchContext was integrated into
  get_provider_ids_matching.
- Corrects the get_sharing_providers docstring s/list/set/ to reflect
  reality.
- Changes a link in the provider-tree doc from the spec-in-progress to
  the merged and published version.

Change-Id: Id433b0540e2051ab27b2c22cc14c62105555ea8f

commit_message:
Replace /var/log/containers/swift symlink with directories

Once we remove the symlinks in update_staks, host_prep_tasks
would create those directories.

Assuming that minor update runs before upgrades, this should
take care of upgrades too.

Change-Id: Idabfec5f568a4e02900d103d23f4cb3c199e84c9
Related-Bug: #1833690
(cherry picked from commit 90d05216b96adaf93dcf36680954328ed1cb053d)

subject: Fix minion config test
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 15:42:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix minion config test

We were missing a mock for the ansible symlink call so it was actually
executing on the host. This fails in our package building environments
because we do not have access to sudo.

Change-Id: I6f2082c6880f313b841fc420bc362a52708b3358
Closes-Bug: #1834347
'}]
commit_message:
Fix minion config test

We were missing a mock for the ansible symlink call so it was actually
executing on the host. This fails in our package building environments
because we do not have access to sudo.

Change-Id: I6f2082c6880f313b841fc420bc362a52708b3358
Closes-Bug: #1834347

commit_message:
Use keystone catalog and fix looking up and storing admin tenant id

Trove is now able to properly use the service catalog [1].

We have another[2] patch that this patch depends-on, which
causes us to have a circular dependency. As the change is minimal,
should be ok to squash them together to be able to fix that role.

The paragraph bellow contains the commit message of the patch that is
being squashed.

The 'Get admin tenant id' task was passing invalid arguments to the
os_project_facts module, and the 'Store admin tenant id' task was not
using the correct variable to retrieve the project id.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/574254/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/665458/

Change-Id: I779ba715d20d83b1efe4f07226a5eadd7e0a1870

commit_message:
Specify the linux-image-kvm kernel for ubuntu

This patch switches to using the linux-image-kvm kernel by default.
It produces images that are about 200MB smaller than ubuntu-minimal with
linux-image-generic by using the linux-image-kvm instead of the
linux-image-generic kernel.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/666063
Change-Id: I4103bcbaab65ed5d7683d35aaf04955e59ed2471

[{'created': '2019-06-24 19:21:23.000000000', 'message': "Validate certificate content at API level

Starting from Rocky, certificates are loaded still at API level when
converting objects to provider data models. The act of loading the
certificate provides validation as to its content. For example, it
checks if a value in the Common Name field is set. When the content is
passed in on create and update actions via reference, it is checked at
API level. If it's invalid, it fails right there and an error is
returned to the user.

Altough, certificate content is not checked at API level in Queens.
Should an invalid certificate be passed in, the API accepts but it will
later fail at provisioning -- the listener and loadbalancer go into
ERROR. The problem starts when the health manager runs the periodic
update health check. It calculates the expected number of listeners and
sees the listener in ERROR. In an attempt to self-heal it, an amphora
failover is triggered. As it runs the failover, it tries, again, to load
up the invalid certificate. Amphora failover goes on in a loop.

This patch is a Queens-only patch.

commit_message:
Validate certificate content at API level

Starting from Rocky, certificates are loaded still at API level when
converting objects to provider data models. The act of loading the
certificate provides validation as to its content. For example, it
checks if a value in the Common Name field is set. When the content is
passed in on create and update actions via reference, it is checked at
API level. If it's invalid, it fails right there and an error is
returned to the user.

Although, certificate content is not checked at API level in Queens.
Should an invalid certificate be passed in, the API accepts but it will
later fail at provisioning -- the listener and loadbalancer go into
ERROR. The problem starts when the health manager runs the periodic
update health check. It calculates the expected number of listeners and
sees the listener in ERROR. In an attempt to heal it, an amphora
failover is triggered. As it runs the failover, it tries, again, to load
up the invalid certificate. Amphora failover goes on in a loop.

This patch is a Queens-only patch.

Task: 34261
Story: 2005925

Change-Id: Ib0fb3db3b2d56345eeeda2014c15e35281bcfec8

Disable SSL certificate validation

Starting from urllib3 1.25.x, it validate SSL certificate by default,
which failed our CI.

subject: Fix error message in RestClientException
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 08:32:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix error message in RestClientException

In RestClientException, self.resp and self.resp_body are never used,
so this is to rewrite the error message to include both resp and
resp_body if not empty.

Change-Id: I3a4119d261c1809d01c041000f66d7ae6eae4da5
'}]
commit_message:
Fix error message in RestClientException

In RestClientException, self.resp and self.resp_body are never used,
so this is to rewrite the error message to include both resp and
resp_body if not empty.

Change-Id: I3a4119d261c1809d01c041000f66d7ae6eae4da5

commit_message:
Add template mode to tripleo-hieradata

Add a new tasks file (hieradata_vars.yaml) to the tripleo-hieradata role
that will create the hieradata files from jinja2 templates that are
included with the role.

The templates will be rendered based off of the values of
host_vars/group_vars/inventory_vars and variable files read out of Heat.

This functionality is a start to migrating the Hiera generation out of
Heat into pure Ansible.

Change-Id: I9ccccbfee44fc7c1375dec7357ccad6cba909c16

commit_message:
Transfer all images in a manifest list

When multi_arch=True, request a manifest list then transfer all images
referenced in that list.

Change-Id: Ie94905120a797d95becc21cc33d63816910b0638
Blueprint: multiarch-support

Hi Soledad, would you be so kind to back port this documentation to the stable/stein branch?

User messages were added in the Pike release, so this documentation can be back ported to all the releases we support. So, once it merges in stable/stein, we'll get it backported to stable/rocky, and then to stable/queens and finally to stable/pike.


To backport this patch, look for the "Cherry pick" button on this review, and type "stable/stein" in the branch. Or, you can also:

  $ cd manila
  $ git fetch --all
  $ git checkout origin/stable/stein
  $ git cherry-pick -x  84e7f4e5426fcee5941b8e4cb6d53040be8cd0ee
  $ # Resolve any merge conflicts
  $ git review'}, {'account_id': 29958, 'date': '2019-06-27 01:09:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

Sure Goutham'}, {'account_id': 29958, 'date': '2019-06-27 01:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit bf829be9999c97acd260bbc16aa4e6a921637886'}]

commit_message:
Fix galera_server installation for openSUSE Leap 15.1

The MariaDB repositories are offering a download repo under
the leap major version, e.g. "opensuse15" or "opensuse42" for all leap
42.x and leap 15.x versions, respectively. There isn't a specific
build for openSUSE Leap 15.1, so the previous logic selected
a repo url of opensuse-151 which does not exist.

Change-Id: Ia0985c03d51c3bfe06b98ae73a3533c3402453e3

commit_message:
Fix quoting in zuul for tempest plugins

Something has changed and the quoting used in the zuul jobs
configuration no longer works[1]. This patch removes the excess
quoting.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/61/665861/6/check/ \
    octavia-v2-dsvm-noop-api/dac4dba/job-output.txt.gz \
    #_2019-06-26_14_13_23_428457

Change-Id: Ib5f55a8885e8f5d39af9f464b2bb71d4bde599f0

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-24 19:39:13.000000000', 'message': 'Speed up source builds for horizon

Source builds of horizon needlessly ran many compilemessages
iterations for core horizon parts because of using horizon
manage.py which referenced openstack_dashboard.settings
This patch switches to django-admin for source builds.

Due to manage.py not being run, the "static" directory
must be created here by us to prevent later breakage.

Change-Id: I737f80566dd263ed291e215968ec72a95ad41a5f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-06-24 19:41:26.000000000', 'message': 'Speed up source builds for horizon

Source builds of horizon needlessly ran many compilemessages
iterations for core horizon parts because of using horizon
manage.py which referenced openstack_dashboard.settings
It caused CentOS builds to take a long time due to their
slow gettext implementation which in turn caused failed jobs
in CI.

This patch switches to django-admin for source builds.

Due to manage.py not being run, the "static" directory
must be created here by us to prevent later breakage.

Change-Id: I737f80566dd263ed291e215968ec72a95ad41a5f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-06-26 17:38:51.000000000', 'message': "Speed up builds for horizon slowed down by recent upstream change

Source builds of horizon needlessly ran many compilemessages iterations
for core horizon parts because of using horizon's manage.py in a loop.
The behavior was caused by recent upstream change ([1]).

It caused CentOS source builds to take too long time and time out in CI.

This patch switches to using django-admin.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4e911e2889ebe7f0a577a0323649dceb9cef363c

Change-Id: I737f80566dd263ed291e215968ec72a95ad41a5f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-06-26 17:45:24.000000000', 'message': "Speed up builds of horizon slowed down by recent upstream change

Builds of horizon needlessly ran many compilemessages iterations for
core horizon parts because of using horizon's manage.py in a loop.
The behavior was caused by recent upstream change ([1]).

It caused CentOS source builds to take too long time and time out in CI.

This patch switches to using django-admin.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4e911e2889ebe7f0a577a0323649dceb9cef363c

Change-Id: I737f80566dd263ed291e215968ec72a95ad41a5f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Speed up builds of horizon slowed down by recent upstream change

Builds of horizon needlessly ran many compilemessages iterations for
core horizon parts because of using horizon's manage.py in a loop.
The behavior was caused by recent upstream change ([1]).

It caused CentOS source builds to take too long time and time out in CI.

This patch switches to using django-admin.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4e911e2889ebe7f0a577a0323649dceb9cef363c

Change-Id: I737f80566dd263ed291e215968ec72a95ad41a5f
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Consider a BOSS card a RAID controller

This fixes the is_raid_controller method so that it returns true
for a BOSS controller in addition to normal RAID controllers.

Change-Id: Iedd3179b8b2b6e3815709cc1acfd6a3059e42399
(cherry picked from commit caff41164f361ad69dc08979882fba47cc3e7bda)

Fix ipaclient script

The parameters for no_ntp_setup, ipa_domain and makehomedir
need to be set to whatever is coming in from heat.

commit_message:
Bumped and hardened linting

- Fixes one bashate problem
- Updates linters
- Addressed most of the skip_list exclusions and removed them

Assure the `pre-commit run -a` is always run on all files instead
of old behavior which allowed linting to be broken when merging.

Bumping operation is mostly automated, we just need to run:
`pre-commit autoupdate` from time to time and fix eventual issues.

Change-Id: If75a3e49a9d570e744063ea35ea41919261ad876

commit_message:
Remove the json_error callback plugin

The json_error callback plugin has been imported into tripleo-ansible
and is no longer required here.

commit_message:
Bump keystone middleware version to 4.18

keystone_authtoken/auth_uri is deprecated. Use www_authenticate_uri
instead.

This is related to this bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/mistral/+bug/1788174

keystonemiddleware in lower constraints should be increased
because www_authenticate_uri was introduced in keystonemiddleware 4.18.0.

Change-Id: I427887467678c11c74382b6805e32d1455641294

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-21 20:23:29.000000000', 'message': 'Retry heat stack polling on gateway problems

If the heat api is overloaded or temporarily unavailable, we might get a
503 or 504 from haproxy during the deployment. We should retry polling
for events in this case as to not prematurely exit the deployment.

commit_message:
Retry heat stack polling on gateway problems

If the heat api is overloaded or temporarily unavailable, we might get a
503 or 504 from haproxy during the deployment. We should retry polling
for events in this case as to not prematurely exit the deployment.

Change-Id: I947cd0f9bf4a97e46c3d2bf3e9b986f7d38e9357
Closes-Bug: #1833452
(cherry picked from commit cb42cfe30fb0ca8f95ae3e7d93e616c106c6c191)

commit_message:
Show all SG rules belong to SG in group's details

If security group contains rule(s) which were created by different
user (admin), owner of this security group should see such rules
even if those rules don't belong to him.

This patch changes to use admin_context to get security group rules
in get_security_group() method to achieve that.

Test to cover such case is added in neutron-tempest-plugin repo.

Change-Id: I890c81bb6eabc5caa620ed4fcc4dc88ebfa6e1b0
Closes-Bug: #1824248

commit_message:
horizon: process i18n files just once

During build of horizon we have a situation where i18n files get
processed several times.

From my debugging it looks like 'manage.py compilemessages' command
already knows how to walk through directories so instead of calling it
per directory we can call it once per 'site-packages'.

Also remove 1100 locale files from django to make it faster.

Change-Id: Icf7289bd5fc02494551a42efc42691df3d8ed290

commit_message:
Move back to CentOS StorageSIG repos for Ceph and Ganesha

Recently a new repo was created in CentOS to distribute Ganesha,
and the repo made a dependency of the Ceph Nautilus repo package [1]

When centos-release-ceph-nautilus 1.2-1 will go out, it should not
be necessary to disable the CentOS Ceph repos pulled in by
dependency of the RDO repositories, as done in [2]

1. https://github.com/CentOS-Storage-SIG/centos-release-ceph/commit/f1a17c9d145cabfa1dfd3102fe7e2fc584f6a907
2. https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651601/

Change-Id: I6bf0cbfaffc22147c5bec03b5897719de53366ed
(cherry picked from commit cf47864ab1e4fa6192ea96727d01b3e935b7a1fc)

commit_message:
Create new image volume cache entry when cloning fails

This patch fixes the image volume cache so that a new cache entry is
created whenever cloning an existing entry fails (which can happen, for
example, when a cached volume reaches its snapshot limit). This restores
the original behavior, which was broken by [1].

[1] I547fb4bcdd4783225b8ca96d157c61ca3bcf4ef4

Closes-Bug: #1801595
Change-Id: Ib5947e2c7300730adb851ad58e898a29f2b88525

commit_message:
Revert "Disable compute shelve tests"

This reverts commit ff6bdd7454695f8a380698c8027f022e88b33e52.

The inability to delete the shelved rbd snapshot image should
be fixed in the dependent nova change so we can enable shelve
testing again (at least on branches that have the nova fix).

Depends-On: If3c9d1de3ce0fe394405bd1e1f0fa08ce2baeda8

Change-Id: I6785d5ca4d42c9f30139f3e7c0f7569d116924b8
Related-Bug: #1653953
Related-Bug: #1697953

commit_message:
Add bindep.txt for Octavia

Some base packages are no longer automatically included in zuul
job runs. This is good as we need to call out our platform package
requirements.
This patch adds a bindep.txt to Octavia to capture those
package requirements.

Change-Id: I48e82f39e3980d6d50e3b710326b8e437eddb08b

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-03-26 09:12:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

i should note for context this is a minimal version of the nova neutron negotiating protocol that i have wanted to add for over 3 years at this point.

in this version i have removed most of the complexity and just record what has happened so there is no negotiation happening between nova and neutron but this has been causing us heartache since icehouse and i would like to actually make some progress in train to removing some of the tech debt.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-03-26 11:56:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

TODO: add Sean as co-author (actually he is the main author of this spec)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-03-27 14:04:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-03-27 14:04:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-03-27 18:42:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-03-27 19:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

by the way https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1813789
is just one bug that we have related to this currently which
we are trying to fix by  not waiting for the network-event
https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bug/1813789+(status:open+OR+status:merged)
but that means we will have silent races instead.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-03-28 09:44:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

fyi in case people dont see it i have leaf a comment on line 100
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/645173/2/specs/train/port-binding-extended-information.rst@100

explaining some of the reason why i took this approch in the first place. there are other feature that i personally would prefer to work on to deliver value to operators and endusers but i also think its important to pay down this technical debt.

im going to try and get some eye on this form the nova side too.
if this is somethign the neutron team feels strongly shoudl not be done i can drop it but i think this needs some discussion at the ptg.

thanks for the feedback so far by the way as there are potentially other avenues to solve some of the issue i have raised and im happy to pursue any that have general support and are likely to be accpted in train.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-29 00:53:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Let's also make sure this is discussed by the Neutron drivers team. I am tagging the RFE (https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1821058) as triaged so it gets in the agenda of the drivers. Hopefully it gets discussed in the meeting  of 3/29 or 4/1"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-03-29 10:21:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2019-03-21 13:41:07.000000000', 'message': 'Port binding event extended information for Nova

There are several cases in the Nova/Neutron/os-vif interaction
where the knowledge of the neutron core plugin or ML2 driver
would be useful to facilitate a more robust handling of guest
networking.

For example, in Icehouse, a external event mechanism was
introduced to allow neutron to notify Nova of network changes
and VIF plugging. As the occasion on which these events are
emitted is dependent on the driver that bound the port and Nova
does not have knowledge of that. Therefore, Nova cannot rely on
the event to synchronize the operation between Nova and neutron,
which has lead to a race condition in the past.

Change-Id: I57f4df31bee83b818f2c0123577d11a8e07c0191
Related-Bug: #1821058

commit_message:
Port binding event extended information for Nova

There are several cases in the Nova/Neutron/os-vif interaction
where the knowledge of the neutron core plugin or ML2 driver
would be useful to facilitate a more robust handling of guest
networking.

For example, in Icehouse, a external event mechanism was
introduced to allow neutron to notify Nova of network changes
and VIF plugging. As the occasion on which these events are
emitted is dependent on the driver that bound the port and Nova
does not have knowledge of that. Therefore, Nova cannot rely on
the event to synchronize the operation between Nova and neutron,
which has lead to a race condition in the past.

Change-Id: I57f4df31bee83b818f2c0123577d11a8e07c0191
Related-Bug: #1821058

messages: [{'account_id': 18152, 'date': '2018-11-06 15:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18152, 'date': '2019-06-26 21:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nHas already been fixed.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-06 15:30:00.000000000', 'message': 'haproxy: allow status 200 on ceph-rgw backend

When the S3 API is enabled on Ceph RadosGW, `HEAD /` returns HTTP 200
instead of HTTP 405 when only the Swift API is enabled.

This commit modifies the HTTP check in the `ceph-rgw-back` backend in
HAproxy to accept both HTTP 200 and HTTP 405 as valid statuses.

Change-Id: I79587051374867468298172d980b8b403b5fe87d
Closes-Bug: #1801950
'}]
commit_message:
haproxy: allow status 200 on ceph-rgw backend

When the S3 API is enabled on Ceph RadosGW, `HEAD /` returns HTTP 200
instead of HTTP 405 when only the Swift API is enabled.

This commit modifies the HTTP check in the `ceph-rgw-back` backend in
HAproxy to accept both HTTP 200 and HTTP 405 as valid statuses.

Change-Id: I79587051374867468298172d980b8b403b5fe87d
Closes-Bug: #1801950

commit_message:
Add bindep.txt for Octavia

Some base packages are no longer automatically included in zuul
job runs. This is good as we need to call out our platform package
requirements.
This patch adds a bindep.txt to Octavia to capture those
package requirements.

Change-Id: I48e82f39e3980d6d50e3b710326b8e437eddb08b

commit_message:
Rename RSD doc file to match title for sorting

The list of driver docs are sorted based on their file names, but since
the name was rsd* but the title was "Intel RSD...", it would show up in
the list out of order. This updates the file name so the sorting works
right.

Change-Id: I9fda67abdf0156d1712c3c5c9013264341dd1511
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-06-16 17:38:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix updated network segmentation_id

This patch fixes 2 issues in updating network's segmentation_id:
1. Wrong context was passed to mech_driver.get_vif_type() method and that
   caused raising AttributeError as "Context" object didn't have attribute
   'current'.
   This patch added new method "get_supported_vif_type" to mechanism drivers
   and this method don't need context to return what vif_types are supported
   regarding agent type.
2. Filter neutron_lib.objects.utils.NotIn, designed to work with OVO objects
   was used in db query and because of that ports belong to network wasn't
   filtered by vif_type thus if there were any ports in network, it was not
   possible to change its segmentation id.

Change-Id: Ic6c738db28208e5009f78bb52598eb3c141f639f
Closes-Bug: #1832985

commit_message:
Fix update of network's segmentation id

In patch [1] there was added usage of context parameter in method
get_vif_type in openvswitch mech_driver.
This exposed that previously "wrong" context was passed to this method
in _update_segmentation_id() method in ml2 plugin and that caused
raising AttributeError as "Context" object didn't have attribute
'current'.

This patch adds new method "get_supported_vif_type" to mechanism
drivers and this method don't need context to return what vif_types
are supported regarding agent type.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658784/

Change-Id: Ic6c738db28208e5009f78bb52598eb3c141f639f
Related-Bug: #1832985

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2019-05-17 01:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

do we automatically create an image store for each cinder backend?
Or do we add some flag per cinder backend to specify if image store for it should be created?
Or something else.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-05-17 02:16:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

@Arkady: good questions.
> do we automatically create an image store for each cinder backend?
> Or do we add some flag per cinder backend to specify if image store for it should be created?
> Or something else.

Under this proposal, the store creation and configuration would all be done in Glance.  The configuration would be manual on the Cinder side.  It would be up to the operator to determine the relation between Cinder volume-types and Glance stores.  There could be a dedicated store per cinder backend, or they might just use the default glance store, or they might all use the "cheap" store.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-05-17 03:47:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Hi Brian,

There is one scenario, when glance is configured to use cinder as a backend store then while uploading the volume to image cinder just creates the location uri and add it as a location to the image.

It needs to be documented at cinder side that;

If glance is using cinder as a store backend then while creating the volume_type operator must choose cinder store to add as a extra_spec argument.

Or

We should just ignore the store specified in the volume_type in this case.

Please suggest!!'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-05-17 11:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> There is one scenario, when glance is configured to use cinder as a
 > backend store then while uploading the volume to image cinder just
 > creates the location uri and add it as a location to the image.
 > 
 > It needs to be documented at cinder side that;
 > 
 > If glance is using cinder as a store backend then while creating
 > the volume_type operator must choose cinder store to add as a
 > extra_spec argument.
 > 
 > Or
 > 
 > We should just ignore the store specified in the volume_type in
 > this case.

Even if Cinder is the backing store, they could still choose to have images created to a different store if that is what is defined in the volume type, right?'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-05-17 11:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> > There is one scenario, when glance is configured to use cinder as
 > a
 > > backend store then while uploading the volume to image cinder
 > just
 > > creates the location uri and add it as a location to the image.
 > >
 > > It needs to be documented at cinder side that;
 > >
 > > If glance is using cinder as a store backend then while creating
 > > the volume_type operator must choose cinder store to add as a
 > > extra_spec argument.
 > >
 > > Or
 > >
 > > We should just ignore the store specified in the volume_type in
 > > this case.
 > 
 > Even if Cinder is the backing store, they could still choose to
 > have images created to a different store if that is what is defined
 > in the volume type, right?

No, at present what cinder is doing is if glance is using cinder backend then first they are creating image in queued state then it creates a volume at cinder side and adds its location with prefix cinder://<image-id> to glance.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-05-22 05:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-06-26 20:20:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

This looks consistent with what we discussed at the PTG.'}]

commit_message:
[CI] Add bindep.txt

Bindep is a tool for checking the presence of binary
packages needed to use an application / library. It
started life as a way to make it easier to set up a
development environment for OpenStack projects.

Infra has been looking to drop the global
bindep_fallback.txt [1][2] file for all
OpenStack projects, they recommend that projects
maintain their own with packages as necessary.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-infra/2018-April/005926.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/006888.html
Change-Id: I1824f132b0ffadc6c9179582d37295f3abed355f
(cherry picked from commit 1709fd7fc222f81bcbedc05e683d2eec5337edcc)
(cherry picked from commit 6ac1730127ddf2f8113e791c3740909bbe05837d)

messages:

Waiting on master to merge'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-22 13:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 30381, 'date': '2019-06-23 22:33:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-06-24 15:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-26 15:30:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-21 12:50:21.000000000', 'message': 'Maintenance task: Fix race condition at resource creation

When the maintenance task runs (every 5 minutes) it should take in
consideration how old is the resource before considering it to be an
inconsitency.

Prior to this patch, what could happen is that a resource being created
was committed to the neutron database but not yet to the OVN database and
ovn_revision_numbers cache table. In the meantime, the maintenance
task could run and create that resource before the create_*_postcommit()
completed resulting in a race condition.

Using a port as an example, the following error would be seeing when
that happens (more detailed example in the LP ticket):

ovsdbapp.backend.ovs_idl.transaction [-] OVSDB Error:
{"details":"Transaction causes multiple rows in \"Logical_Switch_Port\"
table to have identical values (\"89ebd403-68af-43a2-a4e4-5fa86d57d2a2\")
for index on column \"name\".

This patch adds a new filter to the get_inconsistent_resources() method
which checks the "created_at" column of the resource to see if it's older
than 60 seconds and ignore if it's newer.

Closes-Bug: #1833445
Change-Id: If157e9d4660cc6c566ecad44aa6734af2bd14db1
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 1e0c9370b23315d7e734cf5ebc960e76c454bb61)
'}]
commit_message:
Maintenance task: Fix race condition at resource creation

When the maintenance task runs (every 5 minutes) it should take in
consideration how old is the resource before considering it to be an
inconsitency.

Prior to this patch, what could happen is that a resource being created
was committed to the neutron database but not yet to the OVN database and
ovn_revision_numbers cache table. In the meantime, the maintenance
task could run and create that resource before the create_*_postcommit()
completed resulting in a race condition.

Using a port as an example, the following error would be seeing when
that happens (more detailed example in the LP ticket):

ovsdbapp.backend.ovs_idl.transaction [-] OVSDB Error:
{"details":"Transaction causes multiple rows in \"Logical_Switch_Port\"
table to have identical values (\"89ebd403-68af-43a2-a4e4-5fa86d57d2a2\")
for index on column \"name\".

This patch adds a new filter to the get_inconsistent_resources() method
which checks the "created_at" column of the resource to see if it's older
than 60 seconds and ignore if it's newer.

Closes-Bug: #1833445
Change-Id: If157e9d4660cc6c566ecad44aa6734af2bd14db1
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 1e0c9370b23315d7e734cf5ebc960e76c454bb61)

commit_message:
Disable publishing images on Ocata

These jobs have been failing for some time. Stop wasting CI resources
and disable them. We can enable them again if someone maintains ocata
before it gets to EOL.

Change-Id: I117d3a6b09599cfe23981477eb1e85fe9d8154ba

commit_message:
Create ${APACHE_RUN_DIR} if libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 module is installed

The aim of the patch is to creating directory from ${APACHE_RUN_DIR}
variable for:

* aodh
* ceilometer
* horizon
* panko

If an image is built with python3 therefore libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 module
has to be installed accordingly but the module doesn't create /var/run/apache2
directory which is APACHE_RUN_DIR in apache configuration file so apache can't
start without it due to the fact that the directory is used to make there pid,
run, etc files.

Change-Id: Id511a07fca3eec9b5e80f2f9413628ab4d42d61b

commit_message:
Only enable dbus-daemon for fedora-29 and below

In fedora-30 is when we migrate to dbus-broker, fedora-29 is still using
dbus-daemon.

Change-Id: I1e1d3a3826157b8b22386c211eaa58b6439b5f3c
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use neutron-legacy on subnodes in devstack zuul job

There are still some issues with lib/neutron thus neutron-legacy is used
on controller node in multinode jobs and in single node jobs.
But in "group-vars" in devstack job it was configured to use
lib/neutron which can cause some problems in multinode jobs.

So lets switch to neutron-legacy on subnodes also until lib/neutron
will be ready to use everywhere.

Closes-Bug: #1834079

Change-Id: I0d7f9f2baaee2836a719f199939156bd4f53f778
(cherry picked from commit 1b15176b0598f00c442c3b40985df30204dc6963)

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - PowerMax Formatted Vols Fix

PowerMax OS (uCode 5978) arrays support adding volumes to a Metro
RDF group without the need for formatting the volume in advance.
This bug fix addresses a bug in the code where PowerMax volumes
are formatted regardless of support.

Change-Id: Ib840d885c8e3d4d13c9d4bc3c88ef8e5d8477788
Closes-Bug: #1829876

commit_message:
Fix bootstrap node for nova conductor

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - Rapid TDEV Deallocation

Changes made to adding & removing volumes from RDF enabled storage groups
when using new 91 endpoints force flag is needed in established groups.

Volume delete workflow no longer calls deallocation function seperately, this is now
included in volume delete process.

Implements: blueprint powermax-tdev-deallocation

Change-Id: I0d2c129c172c7c2e4126e31a9b07de6178036dfc

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - locking improvements

Adding the serial number of the array to the coordination tag which
will improve replication performance as storage groups and masking
views use the same names on the both the source and target array.

Change-Id: I127dd5f150cee8faa8c4a50d9ffed3f5e057e7bc

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - clone improvements

1.  Bring clone licence exception closer to clone licence check
2.  Throw exception if source volume no longer exists
3.  Retry snapvx cleanup

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - add 'target_array_model' to metadata

Make sure 'target_array_model' gets added to volume metadata in all
cases where replication is enabled.  Initialize it to None to prevent
KeyError exceptions.  Also using traceback for a more explanatory
exception within the decorator method.

Change-Id: I30c2e7a60e12e4f419dd469f1ed04bf03a74c1a8

[{'account_id': 30165, 'date': '2019-04-18 15:09:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-04-18 15:09:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

Wouldn't be recommended to add an upgrade check?"}, {'account_id': 7160, 'date': '2019-06-05 22:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Looks fine.
But I am not clear on the upgrade and positioning.
So for Stein and earlier release you cannot use 9.1 version of unisphere and PowerMAX. For Train you must use 9.1 version.
So one cannot use PowerMAX 9.1 with previous release, nor can one upgrade openstack with PowerMAX to Train since it will use 9.1 rest API with 9.0 version of PowerMAX.

Is there a way to do auto negotiation?'}, {'account_id': 12670, 'date': '2019-06-06 09:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Just to follow on from what Arkady has said, we are hard and fast about minimum versions of Unisphere for PowerMax.  In Train we will be adding 2 features that have been introduced in 9.1, Rapid TDEV Deallocation and Metro ODE.  Our driver will not initialize if on Unisphere for PowerMax 9.0 as the 91 endpoints do not exist.  Let me see if there is a check we can do to see if we can explicitly log an error to upgrade if on an earlier version of Unisphere for PowerMax.  Thanks for the feedback'}, {'account_id': 30165, 'date': '2019-06-06 10:18:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Wouldn't be recommended to add an upgrade check?

Hi Erlon, we can definitely add in an upgrade check for the unisphere version being used with Train. Would it be okay if I added this in a separate change?"}, {'account_id': 23601, 'date': '2019-06-06 14:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > Wouldn't be recommended to add an upgrade check?
 > 
 > Hi Erlon, we can definitely add in an upgrade check for the
 > unisphere version being used with Train. Would it be okay if I
 > added this in a separate change?

We have a call already in there for checking Unisphere major version, that would work fine. If we start it here though we will need to add in version control checks for every release, im in favour of using minimum requirements as we have done in the docs only."}, {'account_id': 26561, 'date': '2019-06-10 01:52:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

run-DellEMC PowerMAX CI'}, {'account_id': 26561, 'date': '2019-06-11 08:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I've added this request in a separate change here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664860"}, {'account_id': 23601, 'date': '2019-06-17 08:20:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-06-20 17:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I agree that this should come with an upgrade check to verify that the endpoint has been updated if the PowerMax driver is configured.'}, {'account_id': 30165, 'date': '2019-06-21 07:51:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I agree that this should come with an upgrade check to verify that
 > the endpoint has been updated if the PowerMax driver is configured.

Hi Jay, I added a version check for meeting minimum endpoint requirements here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664860/2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-21 15:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

> > I agree that this should come with an upgrade check to verify
 > that
 > > the endpoint has been updated if the PowerMax driver is
 > configured.
 > 
 > Hi Jay, I added a version check for meeting minimum endpoint
 > requirements here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664860/2

I believe Jay is referring to adding an upgrade check here:

https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/cmd/status.py#L60'}, {'account_id': 12670, 'date': '2019-06-23 21:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Jay, Sean,
We are still a little unclear how to proceed, as the version check is very specific to our driver and the software we use to interface with the PowerMax OS.  We will circle back with you tomorrow, in the interim, we will bring the contents of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664860 back to this review.  Thanks for the feedback.
Helen'}, {'account_id': 12670, 'date': '2019-06-25 08:38:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks Jay for explaining what needs to happen in status.py. It is not a trivial change as in order to get the 'Unisphere for PowerMax' version we first need to connect to it.  All the connection information is in cinder.conf.  As this will take time to implement and test, I hope you will be in agreement to allow this review to merge and to make the changes in status.py in another review.  The reason I ask is that all of our new features is dependent on this merging and I am mindful of the pending feature freeze and that it is vacation season.  Thank you, Helen"}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-06-26 15:23:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

They have added a check here:  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664860/5 So, I think we are ok now.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-26 15:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
PowerMax driver -  changing from 9.0 to 9.1 REST endpoints

Changing unisphere for powermax REST endpoint from 9.0 to 9.1.

Change-Id: Ie072e1c4cd2db204664896dc4dc0c131a9341d57

subject: Microversion 1.35: root_required

Think I'm going to have to go back toward "late filter" for now.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-16 09:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-16 16:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-16 17:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-16 17:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

PS5:

- Reverts the RequestGroupSearchContext changes. They were wrong, since one RequestGroupSearchContext is allowed to be/include sharing providers.
- Does not yet introduce any new plumbing to make the feature work properly.

and:

- Renames the *internal* representations of root_required/root_forbidden to anchor_required/anchor_forbidden.
- Rewords the documentation to (hopefully) make it clearer that root_required targets the non-sharing tree.

I did it this way because "anchor" is the term that's used/understood internally in the code to represent the concept we're working with; but it's not a term that's exposed to the API consumer. I'm open to suggestions for better names than 'root_required', but IMO it's a good balance between terseness and clarity; the documentation can take up the slack in the latter.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-16 21:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-16 21:22:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)

At PS6, this works.

I still need to write more tests (ideas or test contributions welcomed), but I'm pretty sure the ones that are in there are covering all the changed paths.

Could split this up a bit if folks want (see inline)."}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-17 08:43:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-17 12:45:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(7 comments)

This doesn't terrify me, at least not conceptually.

When this gets closer to being real, if we choose to do it, then some ideas within on making it tidier. We'll also, I think, want an addition to https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/usage/provider-tree.html or its parent to explain when to use any of root_required, required, and required$S and how to mix and match most effectively.

I need to get moving on the nested version of perfload, because I reckon this could be impactful: Much of the time 'anchor_root_ids' will have many members.

I'm a little bit worried because each time I look at this stuff I struggle to remember the answer to "why we need to do this". That's perhaps my fault because I'm tired or stupid or forgetful, but it would be nice for it all to be a bit more immediately obvious. restricting "allocation requests in the response to only those whose (non-sharing) tree's root resource provider satisfies the specified trait requirements" isn't a reason, it's a solution to some reason.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-17 12:47:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Oh: also: I agree with Tetsuro about splitting out the unrelateds.

You might consider adding RequestWideParams in its own patch before adding the two anchor params to it, to isolate the changes.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-17 14:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-17 15:26:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-17 17:46:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-17 20:51:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(3 comments)

Would be good to see more responses to the comments from me and Tetsuro, to make it clear they've landed on your consciousness.

Based on the discussion in IRC, there seems to be general acceptance of the syntax here. I'm still keen to see, eventually, some more full-throated docs on the hows and wheres to use this stuff (see my comments on ps7).

But yeah, unless we can find some other people to review and weigh in, it seems like the 4 people who care have no substantial objections."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-17 22:10:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(18 comments)

> Would be good to see more responses

Sorry dude, I was composing them while working on the code to address
them, and got interrupted, and...

Next time I'll try to be more, "I'll respond to other comments soon," so
you at least know I saw them.

> We'll also, I think, want an addition to https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/usage/provider-tree.html or its parent to explain when to use any of root_required, required, and required$S and how to mix and match most effectively.

(Almost) done in PS10.

> this could be impactful: Much of the time 'anchor_root_ids' will have many members.

Agreed. However, that query only runs if root_required is being
specified.

Optimizing will require a pretty heinous refactor though, as I've hinted
at inline. For instance, it would be lovely to make the anchor trait
search component a JOIN on existing DB queries. But that would entail
shuffling around where those queries start distinguishing between
sharing and non-sharing providers.

Make it, make it right, make it fast. Somebody wise said that.

> I'm a little bit worried because each time I look at this stuff I struggle to remember the answer to "why we need to do this".

Hopefully the user doc change helps a little bit with that. Explaining
in depth why other mechanisms aren't good enough is way out of scope
there, though. I can try to do that in the spec.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-17 22:43:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-18 08:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks for that doc, nice add.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-18 09:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 14:32:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 14:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 18:08:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 20:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 13:50:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-20 17:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

This is looking fairly reasonable but some nits within and some -1 worthy issues on the tests, mostly noted within but I'll summarize here:

* there are some missing tests, first noted in ps6, I've quoted that into a file comment on the gabbit

* some of the tests make assertions about which providers are at play, but then only measure the length of allocation requests. We can check provider summaries and their traits by a pretty direct path in response_json_paths, so it might be worth doing at least some of the time. something like:

    $.provider_summaries["ENVIRON['CN1_UUID']"].traits: [some trait]'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-20 21:35:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 21:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:10:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)

more on the docs'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:17:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:55:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2

(3 comments)

This works as it says on the tin, and I don't want to be in the position of holding up stuff that works. However there are some comments within about some things we can do to improve over time.

On top of that, to everyone who is involved in making this and the other nested magic features go: We are going to need to save a lot of time near the end of the cycle for documentation (what amount to tutorials) and performance work. Let's make sure we have no more bright ideas about features between now and then."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-20 22:57:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-21 04:21:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2019-06-25 02:24:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-26 15:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM'}]

'}, {'created': '2019-06-16 21:10:14.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Microversion 1.35: root_required

TODO: moar gabbi

Microversion 1.35_ adds support for the ``root_required`` query
parameter to the ``GET /allocation_candidates`` API. It accepts a
comma-delimited list of trait names, each optionally prefixed with ``!``
to indicate a forbidden trait, in the same format as the ``required``
query parameter. This restricts allocation requests in the response to
only those whose (non-sharing) tree's root resource provider satisfies
the specified trait requirements.

Story: #2005575
Task: #33753
Change-Id: I76cad83248920fa71da122711f1f763c4ebdb1ba
"}, {'created': '2019-06-17 14:32:18.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Microversion 1.35: root_required

parameter to the ``GET /allocation_candidates`` API. It accepts a

query parameter. This restricts allocation requests in the response to

commit_message:
Microversion 1.35: root_required

Microversion 1.35_ adds support for the ``root_required`` query
parameter to the ``GET /allocation_candidates`` API. It accepts a
comma-delimited list of trait names, each optionally prefixed with ``!``
to indicate a forbidden trait, in the same format as the ``required``
query parameter. This restricts allocation requests in the response to
only those whose (non-sharing) tree's root resource provider satisfies
the specified trait requirements.

This is to support use cases like, "Land my VM on a host that is capable
of multi-attach," or, "Reserve my Windows-licensed hosts for special
use."

Story: #2005575
Task: #33753
Change-Id: I76cad83248920fa71da122711f1f763c4ebdb1ba

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-17 15:26:49.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce RequestWideParams

Recent design discussions have reified the concept that a request to GET
/allocation_candidates has two kinds of query parameters:

- Those that apply to request groups: resources[$S], required[$S], etc.
  Essentially all the ones that can be (optionally) suffixed.
- Those that apply to the request as a whole: limit, group_policy.

Group-specific parameters are already encapsulated in the
placement.lib.RequestGroup class, one instance of which is used to
represent each request group in the query.

This commit pulls the existing request-wide parameters, limit and
group_policy, into a new class, placement.lib.RequestWideParams.

In so doing, it adjusts the signatures of methods which used to use
those individual parameters to use an instance of RequestWideParams as
well.

At the same time, parameters and local variables referring to the list
of RequestGroup are renamed from `requests` to `groups` to
disambiguate/clarify what they are.

Change-Id: I572ec8e6c0f9d81ead49964f41b46ab68a3de9a6
'}, {'created': '2019-06-17 17:46:20.000000000', 'message': 'RequestWideParams and RequestWideSearchContext

placement.lib.RequestGroup class, one instance of which is used to
represent each request group in the query. And then database and other
filtering logic is encapsulated in

This commit pulls the existing request-wide parameters, limit and

In the end, this is just a refactor. No logic is changed.

commit_message:
RequestWideParams and RequestWideSearchContext

Recent design discussions have reified the concept that a request to GET
/allocation_candidates has two kinds of query parameters:

- Those that apply to request groups: resources[$S], required[$S], etc.
  Essentially all the ones that can be (optionally) suffixed.
- Those that apply to the request as a whole: limit, group_policy.

Group-specific parameters are already encapsulated in the
placement.lib.RequestGroup class, one instance of which is used to
represent each request group in the query. And then database and other
filtering logic is encapsulated in
placement.objects.research_context.RequestGroupSearchContext.

This commit pulls the existing request-wide parameters, limit and
group_policy, into a new class, placement.lib.RequestWideParams; and
introduces placement.objects.research_context.RequestWideSearchContext
to encompass the filtering logic for the same.

In so doing, we adjust the signatures of methods which used to use those
individual parameters.

At the same time, parameters and local variables referring to the list
of RequestGroup are renamed from `requests` to `groups` to
disambiguate/clarify what they are.

In the end, this is just a refactor. No logic is changed.

Change-Id: I572ec8e6c0f9d81ead49964f41b46ab68a3de9a6

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-16 21:10:14.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor anchors_for_sharing_providers

At some point anchors_for_sharing_providers was reused in a context
where we needed to use the same algorithm, but retrieve internal IDs
instead of UUIDs. This was done by adding a kwarg triggering slightly
different SQL.

A future patch is going to want both internal IDs *and* UUIDs at the
same time, so this commit refactors anchors_for_sharing_providers to
eliminate the kwarg, run the same SQL every time, and return a
namedtuple called AnchorIds containing all four identifiers (provider
ID, provider UUID, anchor ID, anchor UUID).

Change-Id: I4c2502fe46b354851203e186d7deb1cb3f199fd3

commit_message:
Refactor anchors_for_sharing_providers

At some point anchors_for_sharing_providers was reused in a context
where we needed to use the same algorithm, but retrieve internal IDs
instead of UUIDs. This was done by adding a kwarg triggering slightly
different SQL.

A future patch is going to want both internal IDs *and* UUIDs at the
same time, so this commit refactors anchors_for_sharing_providers to
eliminate the kwarg, run the same SQL every time, and return a
namedtuple called AnchorIds containing all four identifiers (provider
ID, provider UUID, anchor ID, anchor UUID).

Change-Id: I4c2502fe46b354851203e186d7deb1cb3f199fd3

commit_message:
research_context._get_roots_with_traits()

Adds a helper method, _get_roots_with_traits, returning the set of root
provider IDs satisfying required and forbidden trait requirements.

This is needed to implement root_required.

Change-Id: I5a2d386523d336e70aac34f0c455e909019e59ba
Story: #2005575
Task: #33753

commit_message:
Revert "Add a permissive mode for access rules config"

This reverts commit 02540b7de644b35660d1185340a7725b0d5eb0e4.

In the Train PTG[1] we agreed to defer this feature until we had some
kind of traceability or discoverability for APIs and that this wasn't
feasible or useful until then.

This change was merged to master but never released, so I submit that
it is safe to revert.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/keystone-train-ptg-application-credentials

Change-Id: Ieec91dc4739d7ac78f3ff8b8918f4a7a5381ab82

commit_message:
Revert "Add manager support for app cred access rules"

This reverts commit 37fc2b9120538e001daba7093d0295e5f65b811d.

In the Train PTG[1] we agreed to defer the access rules config part of
this feature until we had some kind of traceability or discoverability
for APIs. For simplicity of review, this patch reverts the access rules
addition to the app cred manager so that we can reimplement it in a way
that doesn't require using the access_rules_config API provider.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/keystone-train-ptg-application-credentials

Change-Id: I65ac52b8730221562391adc8b0dbccd22ea79b16

commit_message:
Revert "Add API for /v3/access_rules_config"

This reverts commit 8d31705806721242db6dab34b2c293e317753ea6.

In the Train PTG[1] we agreed to defer this feature until we had some
kind of traceability or discoverability for APIs and that this wasn't
feasible or useful until then.

This change was merged to master but never released, so I submit that
it is safe to revert.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/keystone-train-ptg-application-credentials

Change-Id: Ibb48983f7edef1c2df50ba998f6a95741f933168

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-21 14:10:59.000000000', 'message': 'Remove some synchronization decorators from ip_lib

Removed the synchronization from the following ip_lib functions:
* create_netns
* remove_netns
* list_netns

The mentioned bug #1811515 and the corresponding patch [1], explain
the problem of Pyroute2 NetNS class and the file descriptors used
in a multithread environment. This is why, until a fix is applied to
this library, a synchronization decorator was applied to all Pyroute2
commands.

However, the listed functions do not instantiate this class. These three
methods only handle the filesystem in order to create, remove or list
the system namespaces. That means those methods are not affected by the
mentioned bug in Pyroute2 and it is safe to execute them without any
synchronization.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631275/

Change-Id: I71521efbdaf9bb6d7cd9650f77c52bf6e02c9ced
Closes-Bug: #1833717
Related-Bug: #1811515
'}]
commit_message:
Remove some synchronization decorators from ip_lib

Removed the synchronization from the following ip_lib functions:
* create_netns
* remove_netns
* list_netns

The mentioned bug #1811515 and the corresponding patch [1], explain
the problem of Pyroute2 NetNS class and the file descriptors used
in a multithread environment. This is why, until a fix is applied to
this library, a synchronization decorator was applied to all Pyroute2
commands.

However, the listed functions do not instantiate this class. These three
methods only handle the filesystem in order to create, remove or list
the system namespaces. That means those methods are not affected by the
mentioned bug in Pyroute2 and it is safe to execute them without any
synchronization.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631275/

Change-Id: I71521efbdaf9bb6d7cd9650f77c52bf6e02c9ced
Closes-Bug: #1833717
Related-Bug: #1811515

maintenance but openSUSE 15.1 has been released already. "opensuse-15"
is going to refer to the "latest openSUSE 15.x" build released and
working for OpenStack going forward, so add this nodeset and use
it by default going forward.

Change-Id: I427e1d56384841770deb9c56cd56cbffb2df456b
'}]
commit_message:
Add and switch to the newly created opensuse-15 nodeset

opensuse-150 nodeset is referring to openSUSE 15.0, which is still in
maintenance but openSUSE 15.1 has been released already. "opensuse-15"
is going to refer to the "latest openSUSE 15.x" build released and
working for OpenStack going forward, so add this nodeset and use
it by default going forward.

Change-Id: I427e1d56384841770deb9c56cd56cbffb2df456b

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

1. Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.
2. Update some URLs to latest
3. Remove unncessary "=="

Change-Id: Idcb616fd3add4d58f22b91865cec8a54fe492092

config files.  The experimental nodepool jobs are removed altogether.
